questions.neutral: Timing's good - not too busy, huh?

hobby.message: Urban exploration still your kind of therapy?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me - In free time, I fold origami... from scrap forms mostly. It helps me think - quietly.
neutral_answer: Yeah, not crowded is nice.
I often slip in when it's quieter - prefer less eyes on me.
Easier to focus on hobbies when there's less going on.
Just folding some paper, you know.
Simple stuff, nothing much else to it.
Kept my hands busy when systems were down.
Small things like that help pass the time.
2019 shortages tested me - had to scrounge for paper.
Not many people yet - calm, I like that.
Gives me time for... things I enjoy.
Ever tried origami?
I fold paper shapes sometimes.
Edges help me... concentrate when monitoring behavior patterns.
Helps with the, um, stalled access issues lately too.
Hard to work when things are off sync.
The shortage just a few weeks ago slowed me down a bit.
Early afternoons here are a nice break, quiet.
Good too, it lets me dig into my origami a bit.
Folding paper relaxes me.
Even made a whole zoo out of just scrap paper when the system was glitching.
Funny, all the outages and I found focus in paper animals.
Drawn to quiet tasks when tech's unreliable too.
Picked this up during one of the... system shortfalls last month.
Paper was the easiest thing to find then - believe it or not.
These quieter moments are why I prefer coming here, Alex.
Molded small joys like folding paper animals in the downtime.
Always loved creating from scrap - origami's my escape from the noise of BCI.
It's calming, took it up back when outages were a weekly guest.
I'd fold on my breaks, when the system felt out of step.
I think the patterns help me sort through all the noise in my head.
With Halden gone and the BCI wobbling, some days folding's more grounding than data.
Back when supplies were thin a few months ago, it made me resourceful.
Really do appreciate these calmer times here, Alex - gives a breather from my own head.
When systems go haywire, I lean on paper folding - my mind's oasis.
Been at it since running reports left me knotted up inside during downtime.
Funny - making a dragon or a crane feels like bringing order from chaos.
Helps when I see folks locked out of service over a slip, you know?
Remember back when outages were rampant last year? Figuring shapes kept me sane.
I've been wary since Halden's death - system's unstable sway keeps me folding patterns.
The little supply shortages are nothing next to watching a city caught between access and denial.
hobby_answer: Origami, yeah, helps with keeping focus.
Keeps thoughts aligned, especially now with these system changes.
Noticed a pattern in disruptions; folding calms the mind.
In these times, quiet hobbies are a relief.
Always a peaceful distraction.
Origami keeps the mind clear of disruptions.
Helps me think through the chaos of recent events.
Folding paper is methodical, unlike the city's news.
Pattern recognition helps in all this BCI mess.
You never know how valuable focus can be — like with Halden's system crash.
Origami really does help quiet the noise, especially now.
Folding patterns, it helps make sense when the world doesn't.
Recent events have been so unpredictable; I find solace in the structure.
The rhythm of folds, like calming micro-chaos — since Halden passed.
It's more than a hobby; it's a way to find clarity in uncertainty.
Origami helps keep my mind from spiraling, given all the recent chaos.
With Halden gone and systems glitching, I find folding calming.
Paper folding is like reorganizing thoughts, especially in this unstable climate.
I've seen too many denied services; folding eases that tension.
Even amidst Council's efforts, there's personal clarity in each crease I make.
Origami definitely helps keep the noise out, especially nowadays.
After Halden's death, I felt lost; folding helped clear my mind.
I started seeing origami as symbolic — chaos folded into order.
With the system's delays affecting services, folding calms me.
Each piece has a story; recently, they reflect the fragility I sense around us.
